bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 11, 1876

div1.p: Reed reiterates his devotion to Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 11, 1876

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York H.
Feb. 11, 76

div1.p:
I know
very well that ere this frag-
ment arrives at a certain
town, celebrated in prose &
poetry, I will have received
a good scolding for keep-
ing you in suspense for so
long a time- Why to think, that
almost a whole week, seven
days, will pass before you
hear a word from your own
little boy! My! won't I get
such a lecture! “Sister, why
don't Dr Reed write me a
letter? I think he is the poor-
est correspondent in the
world! I don't intend to answer
his letter when it comes,” etc
etc. Pardon my conceit, my dar-
ling, if such it be; but since
you have a tender feeling
for the writer, I am sure that
the above is just what you
said- And I can't find fault
with you for being a little im-
patient- I know how very anx-
ious I am, if the receipt of
your letter is delayed for even
one day- Bless your darling
little heart! You deserve
much praise for your prompt-
ness in writing to me, ever
since I've been at Willet's
Point; and I, herewith, re-
turn you the sincerest thanks
of a loving heart. This
token of your affection
does not pass unregarded,
but is treasured up in my
heart- and with pride &
pleasure, I welcome the fact
that one of the purest, swee-
test girls, on Earth, values
my friendship sufficiently
to write to me, once a week.
In this connection, I often feel
ashamed of myself when I
have permitted the time to
glide by, which should
have been devoted to you,
my little sweet-heart! Still,
in spite of my best resolves,
this often occurs, & at other
times, I am compelled by cir-
cumstances. Again, I feel so
little in the mood for writing
that I can't string two ideas
together, so as to make good
sense of them- Doubtless,
you have already noticed
this, and it is useless for me
to call your attention to the
fact- You know that this must
be, & is, true, to a greater or
less extent, with every one,
& I am no exception to the rule.
While this is the case, & while
I am, at times, prevented from
writing, yet it is equally
true, that whatever the frame
of my mind may be, or what-
ever work my hand may find
to do, I still have time to think
of you! And this I do always!
Hour after hour, day or night,
working or idling, still do
my thoughts turn to thee, Emilie!
Yes, & I may add, even in my
dre sleeping moments, when
my thoughts are turned adrift,
to roam where e're they will,
often do they lead me to your
side! Nor could there be a
truer test, than this, to show
about what dear object
my waking thoughts delight
to cling- Time after time, have
I dreamed that I was by
your side, even within the
past week- I would hear
your sweet voice as plainly
as if it was not a dream,
and only the arrival of morn,
Cruel morn, would break the
delightful spell! Why, I
dreamed, recently, that you
were telling me that about
some young gentleman
that had proposed to you!
And we had a jolly time, laugh-
ing over his embarrassment-
Doubtless you will say that I
was dreaming of my own confusion
on a certain occasion. At an-
other time, I dreamed that we
were travelling abroad, visit-
ing together & admiring the
wonders of Europe. Of course,
this only goes to show that
we will do this, sometime in
the Future. You know, we
have set our hearts on this,
my darling, & we must do it.
These & others I mieght relate,
all of which proves plainer
than words, that you are
never absent from my
mind-! Absent from my
thoughts! How could it be,
when, day by day, my love
increases! When I addressed you
I thought that I loved you,
and I am sure that I did;
as much as any gentleman
ever loved under the same
circumstances -- but when
I feel the full force of the
boundless love that fills
& warms my heart, now,
I am not forced to admit, but
rather do I gladly confess
that there can be no com-
parison between the two
conditions of my mind-
If this be so, who can
measure my love, when
I shall fold you in my
arms & call you -- wife!
div1.closer:
Ever, my own darling,
your fond & devoted
Walter. (over)
P.S.
In my next letter, I'll tell you
when I am coming to your
to see you -- & it won't be very
long from this time. W.
